title: The Charming Quirks of Others
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Peter offered to drive her back to the house, but she said no, she wanted to walk. She chose her route back along Church Hill, past the furniture shop and the shop where the photographer used to have his premises. J. Wilson Groat, the business used to be called; and she remembered having her first passport photograph taken there, by Mr J. Wilson Groat himself, who had peered from behind a cumbersome-looking  camera and enquired after the teachers at her school, whom he had photographed, he explained, over the years, going back . . . oh, a long time, of course, when Edinburgh had so many photographers to make a record of the life of the city.

title: The Comfort of Saturdays
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: 'Right,' said Jamie. 'I know the cardinal, the one who lives over at Church Hill, in that house with the green copper dome. He must know the Pope.

title: The Lost Art of Gratitude
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: She crossed the road at Church Hill and made her way along the road to the gateway of West Grange House. Peter was in the garden, bending over to examine something in a flower bed, and was alerted to the arrival of Isabel by the barking of his dog.

title: Sunshine on Scotland Street
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Perhaps, as was most probably the case, he had merely forgotten what had happened before; dogs are not ones to linger on the past if there is the prospect of investigating new smells and marking out new territory. Now, as they made their way up towards the Church Hill theatre, Cyril gave every appearance of enjoying himself, wagging his tail

title: The judge,
author: West, Rebecca
snippet: "Yes, it's cairtainly sober," said Ellen placidly. "Beauty, indeed ! I'm past thinking of beauty, after having been up all night giving mother her medicine and encouraging her, and getting her ready in the morning for the ambulance, and going away over to the doctor at Church Hill for my injection this afternoon. I fear to think what I'm looking like, though doubtless  it would do me good to know."

title: Glances on the wing at foreign lands,
author: Hoyt, James M.
snippet: Turning into a narrow street at the rear of the University of Edinburgh and at the head of what was called the college ^'wind" or path up the hill, we saw vacant ground which was the site of the dwelling, now removed, in which Walter Scott was born. We then drove out to Church Hill in Morning Side, in the environs of the city, and saw the house where Chalmers lived and died. We visited the "Grange," or South Cemetery, where he is buried, and saw his grave.

title: The Lost Art of Gratitude
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: 'We got chatting. I was walking back up to Church Hill as I had to go to the supermarket. I mentioned to him that we'd recently met up with Minty again.

title: Sunshine on Scotland Street
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "We're in Church Hill, actually," she said. "But I suppose you weren't to know."

title: Bertie Plays the Blues
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "44 Scotland Street," said Bertie. "But Ranald Braveheart Macpherson lives in Church Hill. He's got this house with a swing in a tree and . . ."
